The morning sun cast long shadows across Kempenfelt Bay as Marcus Thompson laced up his worn running shoes on the front porch of his modest townhouse. The familiar ritual of preparing for his daily run had become second nature over the past fifteen years, but today felt different somehow. There was an electricity in the air that had nothing to do with the approaching storm clouds gathering over Lake Simcoe.

"You're up early again," came the sleepy voice of David from behind the screen door. Marcus turned to see his husband of eight years standing there in his rumpled pajamas, dark hair sticking up at impossible angles, holding two steaming mugs of coffee.

"Couldn't sleep," Marcus replied, accepting the offered mug gratefully. "Keep thinking about that phone call yesterday."

David settled onto the porch swing beside him, close enough that their shoulders touched. At thirty-four, Marcus still maintained the lean build of a serious runner, though the lines around his eyes spoke of years spent training under the harsh Canadian sun. David, two years younger and softer around the edges from his work as an accountant, had always been the practical one in their relationship.

"The talent show thing?" David asked, though he already knew the answer. They'd talked about little else since Marcus received the call informing him he'd made it through to the final round of Canada's Greatest Talent, a nationally televised competition that had been his secret obsession for months.

Marcus nodded, setting down his coffee to stretch his hamstrings against the porch railing. "I still can't believe they picked me. Out of thousands of applicants across the country, they want to see my running routine in the finals."

It hadn't been a traditional audition. Marcus had submitted a video of himself performing what he called "artistic running" – a combination of his natural speed and agility with choreographed movements that told a story through motion. He'd been inspired by watching his niece's dance recital the previous year, struck by how movement could convey emotion in ways that words never could.

The video he'd submitted showed him running through various locations around Barrie – along the waterfront, through Springwater Park, up and down the steep hills of the residential areas – but it wasn't just running. He'd incorporated elements of interpretive dance, using his entire body to express themes of struggle, perseverance, and ultimate triumph. The piece he'd created was called "Breaking Free," and it chronicled his own journey from a closeted teenager afraid to be himself to a man who'd found love and acceptance.

"When's the taping again?" David asked, though Marcus knew he remembered perfectly well.

"Next Thursday. They want all the finalists in Toronto by Wednesday evening for rehearsals." Marcus began his pre-run stretching routine, a series of movements so ingrained they required no conscious thought. "The show goes live on Friday night, prime time. Winner gets fifty thousand dollars and a chance to tour across Canada."

David was quiet for a moment, watching as Marcus worked through his stretches. They'd been together long enough that David could read his husband's moods like a favorite book, and right now he sensed an undercurrent of anxiety beneath Marcus's excitement.

"What aren't you telling me?" David asked gently.

Marcus paused mid-stretch, his expression shifting almost imperceptibly. This was the conversation he'd been dreading since yesterday's phone call. "They're not covering travel expenses for the finalists. I guess I assumed they would, but apparently that's only for the semi-finals and beyond if you make it that far."

"Okay, so we buy you a train ticket to Toronto. It's what, forty dollars?"

"It's not just the train ticket." Marcus resumed his stretching, not quite meeting David's eyes. "They want us there Wednesday through Saturday. Four nights in a hotel, meals, and I'd need to take time off work. Jim's already been on my case about taking too many personal days."

David set down his coffee mug with a soft clink. As the family's financial planner, he knew exactly how tight their budget had become over the past few months. His accounting firm had cut everyone's hours back in January, and Marcus's job at the sporting goods store barely covered their basic expenses. They'd been living paycheck to paycheck since David's mother had needed help with her medical bills the previous fall.

"How much are we talking about?" David asked, though from Marcus's expression he suspected he didn't want to know the answer.

"Best case scenario, if I stay somewhere cheap and eat nothing but fast food, probably around four hundred dollars. More realistically, closer to six or seven hundred."

David felt his stomach drop. They had maybe two hundred dollars in their checking account, and payday wasn't until the following Friday. Their credit cards were already maxed out from the expenses related to David's mother, and they'd borrowed against their small savings account twice already this year.

"We'll figure it out," David said automatically, though privately he was running through their options and coming up empty.

Marcus finally looked at him directly, and David could see the conflict written across his features. "Maybe I should just call them and withdraw. Tell them something came up."

"Absolutely not." David's response was immediate and firm. "This is your dream, Marcus. You've been working toward something like this your entire life."

It was true. Even when they'd first met at a New Year's Eve party nine years ago, Marcus had talked about wanting to find a way to combine his love of running with performance. He'd run competitively in high school and college, but had never been quite fast enough for the Olympic trials or professional circuits. The artistic running concept had emerged gradually over the years, starting as something he did just for fun during his solo training runs and evolving into something more structured and intentional.

"My dream doesn't matter if we can't afford groceries next month," Marcus said, but David could hear the disappointment in his voice.

"Let me look at our finances again tonight," David said. "Maybe I can pick up some freelance bookkeeping work this week. Mrs. Patterson has been asking me to help her organize her small business accounting."

Marcus smiled, but it didn't reach his eyes. "I love that you want to make this work, but I've seen our bank statements too. We both know the money just isn't there."

David stood up and pulled Marcus into a hug, breathing in the familiar scent of his husband's shampoo mixed with the faint smell of coffee. "We have six days to figure this out. Don't give up yet."

Marcus returned the embrace, allowing himself a moment to draw strength from David's unwavering support. This was why he'd fallen in love with this man – David's absolute refusal to let him settle for less than his dreams, even when practical considerations made those dreams seem impossible.

"I should get my run in," Marcus said finally, pulling back from the hug. "Clear my head a little bit."

"How far today?"

"Just five miles. I want to work on some of the choreography for the routine I'd perform if..." he trailed off, not wanting to jinx anything by talking about it too confidently.

David kissed him softly. "When you get there. When you perform your routine."

After Marcus disappeared down the street, his familiar red running shirt becoming a small dot in the distance, David remained on the porch with his coffee. He pulled out his phone and began scrolling through their banking app, looking for any overlooked source of funds. Their mortgage payment was due in two weeks, along with the car payment and David's student loan. They'd already cut their expenses to the bare minimum – cancelled their streaming services, started shopping at discount grocery stores, hadn't eaten at a restaurant in months.

The irony wasn't lost on him that Marcus's potential prize money would solve all their immediate financial problems, but they needed money to give him the chance to win money. It was the kind of catch-twenty-two situation that seemed to define their lives lately.

David's phone rang, interrupting his brooding. The caller ID showed his sister Jennifer's name.

"Morning, Jen. You're up early."

"Kids had me up at five-thirty for some reason. I figured I might as well embrace it and get some work done before they wake up again." Jennifer was a single mother of twin seven-year-olds and somehow managed to run her own graphic design business from home. David had no idea how she did it. "How are things with you guys?"

"Good. Well, mostly good." David found himself explaining about Marcus's opportunity and their financial dilemma.

"Oh wow, that's incredible about the talent show! I remember Marcus showing me some of those videos he made. He's really talented." Jennifer paused. "And really broke, apparently. How much did you say you need?"

"We can probably make it work with around four hundred dollars, but honestly even that feels impossible right now."

"I wish I could help, but with the kids starting soccer and needing new school clothes..." Jennifer's voice trailed off apologetically.

"I wasn't asking," David said quickly. "Just needed to talk it through with someone."

"What about Mom? Did you tell her about this?"

David hesitated. His mother lived in Ottawa and had been incredibly supportive when he'd come out and later when he'd married Marcus. But she was seventy-two and living on a fixed income, and he'd already asked her for help twice in the past year.

"I don't want to burden her with this," he said finally.

"Dave, she would want to know. And she might surprise you."

After they hung up, David sat on the porch swing and watched the neighborhood come alive around him. Mrs. Chen from next door was tending to her garden, and the Kowalski kids were riding their bikes in circles in their driveway. It was the kind of peaceful suburban scene that usually filled him with contentment, but today it felt somehow inadequate.

He'd grown up in Barrie, gone to university in Toronto, and returned home after graduation with vague plans of saving money for a year before moving to a bigger city. That year had turned into nine years, and somewhere along the way he'd stopped thinking about leaving. Meeting Marcus had anchored him here, and most of the time he was happy with their quiet life. But moments like this made him wonder if they'd been too cautious, too willing to settle for stability over opportunity.

His phone buzzed with a text message from his boss at the accounting firm: "Can you come in today? Jenkins called in sick and we have three client meetings scheduled."

David stared at the message for a long moment. It was his day off, and he'd planned to spend it working on their household budget and maybe doing some yard work. But extra hours meant extra money, even if it wasn't nearly enough to solve their current problem.

He texted back his agreement and went inside to shower and change clothes. As he got dressed, he found himself looking at the framed photograph on their dresser from their wedding day. They'd gotten married at a small ceremony in David's parents' backyard, surrounded by family and a handful of close friends. Marcus looked impossibly young in the photo, beaming as they cut their modest wedding cake. David remembered how certain they'd both felt that day that love would be enough to overcome any obstacles life threw at them.

The accounting firm of Peterson & Associates occupied the second floor of a converted heritage building in downtown Barrie. David had been working there for six years, starting as a junior associate and gradually working his way up to senior accountant. It wasn't glamorous work, but he was good at it and found satisfaction in helping clients organize their financial lives.

"Thanks for coming in on short notice," said Margaret Peterson when he arrived at the office. She was a woman in her early fifties who'd built the firm from nothing over the past twenty years. David respected her enormously, both professionally and personally. She'd been nothing but supportive when he'd needed time off for family emergencies, and she'd even attended his wedding.

"No problem. What do we have today?"

"The Hendersons at ten to go over their small business taxes, Mrs. Liu at noon for retirement planning, and the Jakobsons at two-thirty for their divorce settlement." Margaret handed him three manila folders. "Should be straightforward, but I know you like to review everything beforehand."

David settled at his desk and began reviewing the files, but found his concentration wandering. The Henderson file reminded him of Marcus's long-abandoned dream of opening his own running store someday. Mrs. Liu's retirement planning made him think about their own complete lack of retirement savings. And the Jakobsons' divorce settlement just made him grateful that whatever problems he and Marcus faced, they faced them together.

His first client meeting went smoothly. Tom and Linda Henderson had opened a small bakery the previous year and were struggling to understand their quarterly tax obligations. David walked them through the paperwork and set up a system for tracking their expenses that would make next year's filing much simpler.

"You're a lifesaver," Linda said as they prepared to leave. "We were completely overwhelmed by all of this."

"That's what I'm here for," David replied, but privately he was thinking about how the Henderson's bakery represented exactly the kind of entrepreneurial risk that he and Marcus had never been willing to take.

During his lunch break, David walked down to the waterfront and found himself standing at the same spot where Marcus often started his artistic running routines. He could picture his husband moving through the choreographed sequence – the initial slow, contemplative movements giving way to explosive bursts of speed, the way Marcus used the natural landscape as a stage for his storytelling.

David pulled out his phone and called his mother in Ottawa.

"David! What a lovely surprise. How are you, sweetheart?"

"I'm good, Mom. Listen, I wanted to tell you about something exciting that's happening with Marcus."

He explained about the talent show opportunity, trying to keep his tone upbeat and positive. His mother listened without interrupting, asking occasional clarifying questions.

"That's wonderful news! I'm so proud of him. When is the show?"

"Friday night, live on television. The thing is..." David found himself unable to continue, the words sticking in his throat.

"What is it, honey?"

"We're having trouble coming up with the money for him to get there and stay for the week. I feel terrible even mentioning it to you, especially after you helped us out with the car repair and everything, but I didn't know who else to talk to."

His mother was quiet for a long moment. "How much do you need?"

"Mom, I wasn't calling to ask for money. I just needed to talk to someone about it."

"David Michael Chen-Thompson, how much do you need?"

David smiled despite himself. His mother only used his full hyphenated name when she was being serious. "Probably around four hundred dollars, maybe five hundred to be safe."

"Consider it done. I'll transfer the money this afternoon."

"Mom, I can't ask you to do that."

"You're not asking. I'm offering. Marcus is part of this family, and this is his chance to shine. Besides, I've been saving up for a new couch, but the old one is perfectly comfortable for a few more months."

David felt tears prick at his eyes. "I don't know how to thank you."

"Just make sure I know what channel to watch on Friday night. I want to see my son-in-law on television."

After he hung up, David sat on a bench overlooking the bay and allowed himself to feel genuinely excited for the first time since Marcus had gotten the call. This was really happening. Marcus was going to get his chance to perform on national television, to share his unique artistic vision with the entire country.

He spent the rest of his lunch break calling hotels near the television studio in Toronto, eventually finding a small budget hotel that offered weekly rates. It wasn't glamorous, but it was clean and safe and within walking distance of the studio. He made a reservation using their credit card, knowing that his mother's transfer would cover it.

His afternoon client meetings passed in a blur of spreadsheets and tax forms, but David found himself energized in a way he hadn't been in months. There was something powerful about taking action to support the person you loved, about refusing to let financial constraints dictate the limits of possibility.

When he got home that evening, Marcus was in the kitchen preparing dinner – pasta with vegetables from their small garden and a simple tomato sauce. It was humble food, but Marcus had a way of making even the simplest meals feel special.

"How was work?" Marcus asked, looking up from the stove.

"Good. Actually, really good." David couldn't keep the smile off his face. "I talked to my mother today."

Marcus raised an eyebrow. "Oh?"

"She's transferring us five hundred dollars for your Toronto trip. She says she wants to watch her son-in-law on national television."

Marcus stared at him for a long moment, then set down his wooden spoon and pulled David into a fierce hug.

"I can't believe it," Marcus whispered against David's shoulder. "This is really happening."

"This is really happening," David confirmed, holding his husband tightly. "You're going to Toronto, you're going to perform your routine, and you're going to be amazing."

They held each other in the small kitchen as steam rose from the pasta pot and the evening sun slanted through the windows. For the first time in months, their modest life felt not like a limitation but like a foundation – solid ground from which Marcus could leap toward his dreams.Chapter 2

The following morning arrived gray and drizzly, with the kind of persistent Ontario rain that seemed to seep into everything. Marcus stood at the kitchen window, watching droplets race down the glass while his coffee grew cold in his hands. The excitement from the previous evening had given way to a familiar anxiety that settled in his chest like a stone. He'd barely slept, his mind cycling through endless variations of what could go wrong in Toronto. What if his routine wasn't good enough? What if the other contestants were more polished, more professional? What if he froze up in front of the cameras and made a fool of himself on national television?

David emerged from the bedroom already dressed for work, his hair still damp from the shower. He moved through their morning routine with practiced efficiency – grabbing his travel mug from the cabinet, checking his phone for messages, gathering the papers he'd need for the day's client meetings. But Marcus noticed the way his husband's eyes kept finding him, the gentle assessment that meant David was reading his mood and adjusting accordingly.

"The rain's supposed to clear up by this afternoon," David said, settling beside Marcus at the small kitchen table with his own coffee. "Perfect running weather once the temperature drops a bit."

Marcus nodded absently, still staring out at the gray morning. "I keep thinking about what happens if I don't win. We'll have spent all that money for nothing, and I'll just be the guy from Barrie who thought he could dance while running." He finally turned away from the window, meeting David's steady gaze. "What if this whole thing is just some elaborate form of self-delusion? Maybe I'm not actually talented, maybe I'm just different enough that people don't know how to tell me the truth."

David reached across the table and covered Marcus's hand with his own. "Do you remember what you told me after that first time I saw you perform your routine? This was maybe three years ago, down at the waterfront. You'd been working on that piece about overcoming fear, and afterward I asked you why you did it."

Marcus smiled slightly at the memory. "I said it was the only time I felt like my body was saying exactly what I meant it to say."

"And that's still true, isn't it? When you're out there moving through your choreography, you're not performing for anyone else's approval. You're translating something internal into something physical, something visible." David squeezed his hand gently. "The fact that other people connect with it, that Canada's Greatest Talent saw something worth putting on television, that's just confirmation of what I already knew. You have a gift, Marcus. A real, legitimate gift."

The validation helped, but Marcus found himself thinking about the practical realities of the competition. "I've been researching the other finalists online. There's a twelve-year-old violinist who's already performed with the Toronto Symphony Orchestra. A comedian who's been headlining clubs in Vancouver for five years. A dance troupe from Montreal that's won international competitions." He pulled out his phone and showed David the Canada's Greatest Talent website, scrolling through professional headshots and impressive biographies. "And then there's me. Thirty-four-year-old guy from Barrie who works at a sporting goods store and runs around in interpretive patterns."

David studied the website for a moment, taking in the polished promotional materials and carefully crafted contestant profiles. "You know what I notice about all of these descriptions? They're all talking about technical achievements, awards, recognition from established institutions." He looked back at Marcus thoughtfully. "But none of them are talking about heart. None of them are talking about the kind of authentic emotional connection that you create when you perform."

"Heart doesn't win competitions," Marcus replied, though he could hear the doubt in his own voice.

"Maybe not. But it's what makes people remember you long after the competition is over." David stood up and began clearing their coffee mugs, moving through the familiar domestic choreography of their shared morning routine. "Besides, they didn't choose you by accident. Out of thousands of applicants, they saw something in your audition video that made them want more. Trust that instinct."

After David left for work, Marcus found himself alone with the peculiar energy that always preceded a major life event. He'd requested the week off from his job at Northern Sports, though his manager Jim had made it clear that he wasn't happy about the short notice. The store was heading into their busy fall season, and Marcus's absence would mean longer hours for everyone else. The guilt about that added another layer to his anxiety, but David had been right when he'd pointed out that opportunities like this didn't wait for convenient timing.

Marcus decided to spend the morning working on his routine, using their small living room as a makeshift rehearsal space. He'd performed the piece dozens of times over the past few weeks, refining the movements until they felt like second nature, but something about the approaching competition made everything feel uncertain again. The routine that had seemed powerful and moving in the familiar context of Barrie's waterfront trails suddenly felt inadequate when he imagined it on a television stage in front of millions of viewers.

The piece he'd prepared for the finals was an evolution of the "Breaking Free" routine from his audition video, expanded and refined to fill the five-minute time slot he'd been allotted. It began with slow, constrained movements that suggested imprisonment or limitation, gradually building through increasingly dynamic sequences that represented struggle, breakthrough, and ultimately liberation. The emotional arc was deeply personal, drawn from his own experience of accepting his sexuality and finding love, but he'd crafted it to speak to universal themes of overcoming obstacles and embracing authentic identity.

Working through the routine in their living room felt awkward and cramped. The movements that flowed naturally across open landscape felt stilted when performed between their couch and coffee table. Marcus found himself second-guessing choreographic choices that had felt inspired just weeks earlier. Should the initial sequence be slower, more contemplative? Was the transition to the explosive middle section too abrupt? Did the final triumphant movements read as genuine celebration or forced optimism?

By noon, he was frustrated and sweating despite the cool temperature. The routine felt mechanical, disconnected from the emotional truth that had originally inspired it. He decided to abandon the indoor rehearsal and head out for a run, hoping that movement through familiar territory would help him reconnect with the spirit of the piece.

The rain had stopped as David had predicted, leaving the air clean and cool with that particular freshness that followed Ontario storms. Marcus made his way down to the waterfront, nodding to the handful of other runners and dog walkers who were taking advantage of the break in the weather. The path along Kempenfelt Bay had been his training ground for years, and he knew every hill, every turn, every spot where the light fell differently depending on the time of day.

He started with an easy warm-up pace, letting his body settle into the familiar rhythm of foot strike and breath. This was the foundation of everything – the simple, meditative act of running that had been his constant companion since high school. Before the artistic elements, before the choreography, before the dreams of performance and recognition, there had been this: the pure joy of movement, the sense of freedom that came from pushing his body through space under his own power.

As his muscles warmed and his breathing deepened, Marcus began to incorporate elements of his routine. But instead of forcing the predetermined choreography, he let the movements emerge organically from his mood and the environment around him. A flock of geese taking flight from the bay inspired a series of ascending leaps. The way sunlight broke through the clouds and scattered across the water suggested a sequence of turning, spiraling movements that felt like celebration.

This was what David had been talking about – the difference between technical execution and authentic expression. When Marcus stopped trying to perform his routine and instead allowed his body to respond to the landscape and his own internal state, the movements regained their power and meaning. He wasn't just a guy running in interpretive patterns; he was a storyteller using his entire being as the medium for the story.

He spent nearly an hour working through different sections of the routine, experimenting with variations and refinements. A couple of times he noticed other people along the waterfront path stopping to watch, but instead of feeling self-conscious, he found their attention energizing. This was what performance was supposed to feel like – not the anxious attempt to meet external expectations, but the generous sharing of something authentic and meaningful.

By the time he made his way home, Marcus felt more centered than he had since receiving the phone call about the finals. The routine was good – more than good, it was genuinely powerful. He might not have the conventional credentials of some of the other contestants, but he had something that couldn't be taught in any academy or conservatory: a unique voice and the courage to use it.

David was already home when Marcus walked through the front door, sitting at their small dining table with his laptop open and papers spread around him. He looked up as Marcus entered, taking in his husband's flushed cheeks and bright eyes.

"Good run?" David asked, though Marcus's improved mood was obvious.

"Great run. I think I was overthinking everything this morning. Got back out to the waterfront and remembered why I do this in the first place." Marcus grabbed a glass of water and settled across from David at the table. "What are you working on?"

"Travel logistics, mostly. I've got your train tickets booked for Wednesday morning, arriving in Toronto at noon. The hotel reservation is confirmed, and I found a couple of decent restaurants within walking distance that won't break our budget." David turned his laptop screen toward Marcus, showing a detailed itinerary he'd prepared. "I also called the studio and confirmed the rehearsal schedule. You've got a technical run-through Wednesday at four, dress rehearsal Thursday afternoon, and then the live show Friday evening."

Marcus studied the schedule, feeling a mix of excitement and nervousness at seeing it all laid out so concretely. "This is really happening, isn't it?"

"This is really happening. And I have something else to tell you." David's expression shifted to something Marcus couldn't quite read – not bad news, but something significant. "I called in a couple of favors at work and managed to rearrange my client meetings for the end of the week. I'm coming with you."

Marcus stared at him. "David, we can't afford for both of us to go. The hotel room alone will cost more, and you'll miss work, and—"

"The hotel room costs the same whether it's one person or two people. I can bring my laptop and work remotely Thursday and Friday if needed. And honestly, the idea of you going through this alone while I sit here in Barrie worrying about you sounds terrible." David reached across the table and took Marcus's hand. "I want to be there. I want to watch you perform live, and I want to celebrate with you afterward regardless of what happens."

The gesture was so typical of David – quietly figuring out how to make something work, prioritizing Marcus's needs over his own comfort and convenience. Marcus felt a rush of gratitude so intense it was almost overwhelming. "Are you sure? I know how much you hate being away from home."

It was true. David was a creature of routine and familiar surroundings. He'd grown up in Barrie, gone to university in Toronto but come home every weekend, and had never shown any interest in travel or adventure for its own sake. The farthest they'd traveled together was a long weekend in Ottawa to visit David's mother, and even that had required weeks of planning and preparation.

"I hate the idea of missing this more than I hate being away from home," David said simply. "This is the biggest thing that's ever happened to you professionally. There's no way I'm watching it on television when I could be there in person."

They spent the rest of the afternoon working through the practical details of the extended trip. David called his mother to give her the updated schedule, and she immediately insisted that they stay an extra day in Toronto so she could drive down from Ottawa to take them out for a celebration dinner. Marcus called his sister in Thunder Bay to make sure she knew to watch the show, and found himself explaining his artistic running concept to her teenage daughters, who seemed genuinely fascinated by the idea.

As evening approached, they prepared dinner together in their small kitchen, working around each other with the practiced ease of years of shared domestic life. Marcus found himself paying attention to these small moments – the way David hummed unconsciously while chopping vegetables, the familiar ritual of setting their table, the comfortable silence that fell between them as they ate. In three days, they would be in Toronto, surrounded by television cameras and production crews and the intense energy of live broadcast. But this – their quiet life in Barrie, their modest home, their simple routines – this would still be here waiting for them when they returned.

After dinner, they walked down to the waterfront together, following the same route Marcus had taken during his afternoon run. The sun was setting over Lake Simcoe, painting the sky in shades of orange and pink that reflected off the still water. Other couples and families were out enjoying the mild evening, and Marcus felt a deep sense of belonging to this place and these people.

"Whatever happens in Toronto," Marcus said as they settled on a bench overlooking the bay, "I'm grateful for this. For you, for the opportunity, for the fact that we figured out how to make it work."

David leaned against his shoulder, solid and warm in the cooling air. "Whatever happens in Toronto, we'll handle it together. But I have a good feeling about this, Marcus. I think you're going to surprise a lot of people."

They sat in comfortable silence as the light faded and the first stars began to appear in the darkening sky. In less than seventy-two hours, Marcus would be performing his routine on national television, sharing his unique artistic vision with millions of viewers across Canada. The thought was both thrilling and terrifying, but sitting there with David beside him and the familiar landscape of home spread out before them, Marcus felt ready for whatever came next.Chapter 3

Wednesday morning arrived with the kind of crisp autumn clarity that made everything seem possible. Marcus woke before his alarm, his body humming with nervous energy that felt different from the anxiety of the past few days. This was anticipation now, the electric feeling of standing at the edge of something significant. David was already awake beside him, propped up on one elbow and watching Marcus with the patient attention he'd perfected over their years together.

"How are you feeling?" David asked, his voice still rough with sleep.

Marcus considered the question seriously, taking inventory of the sensations coursing through him. His stomach was tight with nerves, but underneath that was a steady current of excitement that reminded him of Christmas mornings as a child. "Scared. Excited. Ready, I think." He rolled over to face David fully. "I keep thinking about all the things that could go wrong, but then I remember how the routine felt yesterday afternoon by the water. It's good, David. Whatever happens with the competition part, the art itself is good."

They had packed the night before, laying out everything Marcus would need for the week in Toronto. His performance outfit – simple black athletic wear that would allow for maximum movement – was folded carefully in tissue paper. David had insisted on bringing their good camera to document the experience, and Marcus had packed the journal he'd been keeping throughout his artistic running journey, thinking he might want to write about whatever happened in the coming days.

The train to Toronto departed at nine-thirty, which meant they needed to leave Barrie by eight-fifteen to account for parking and ticket collection. As they moved through their morning routine – shower, coffee, final check of their luggage – Marcus found himself memorizing details of their ordinary life. The way morning light slanted through their kitchen window, the familiar sounds of their neighborhood waking up, the comfortable rhythm of preparing for a day that they'd repeated hundreds of times before. After today, something fundamental would be different. Win or lose, succeed or fail, he would never again be the person who had only dreamed of performing his art on a national stage.

David loaded their bags into their modest Honda Civic while Marcus did a final walk-through of the house. He found himself pausing in their living room, looking at the space where he'd rehearsed so many times over the past weeks. The furniture was pushed back against the walls to create a makeshift performance area, and suddenly the room felt too small to contain all the dreams and preparation it had witnessed. In a few hours, he would be in a professional television studio with proper lighting and sound equipment and an audience of millions. The thought made him dizzy with possibility.

"Ready?" David called from the doorway, keys jingling in his hand.

Marcus took one more look around their home, then nodded. "Ready."

The drive to the train station passed in comfortable conversation about logistics and timing, but Marcus could sense the undercurrent of significance that ran beneath their practical planning. This wasn't just a trip to Toronto; this was the culmination of years of artistic development and personal growth. Every choice they'd made – David's decision to come along, his mother's financial support, Marcus's commitment to taking time off work despite his manager's disapproval – had led them to this moment.

At the station, they joined the moderate crowd of Wednesday morning travelers heading into the city. Business people with laptops and coffee, students returning to university after a long weekend at home, tourists with cameras and guidebooks. Marcus wondered if any of them would be watching Canada's Greatest Talent on Friday night, if they would remember seeing him on the train when his face appeared on their television screens. The thought felt surreal, like imagining himself as a character in someone else's story.

The train pulled into Union Station just after noon, and Marcus felt his breath catch as the Toronto skyline came into view through the window. He'd been to the city many times over the years – for concerts, shopping trips, visits to museums – but this time felt different. This time, he wasn't just visiting Toronto; Toronto was expecting him. His name was on a list at a television studio somewhere in this sprawling urban landscape. Production assistants were preparing rehearsal schedules that included his slot. Cameramen were testing equipment that would soon be focused on him. We learn how to navigate the entertainment industry while staying grounded in the values and relationship that brought us this far." He paused, taking Marcus's hand in the familiar gesture that had anchored them both throughout this entire experience. "Most importantly, we celebrate what you've achieved and start planning the next phase of your artistic journey, whatever that might look like."

The morning sun cast long shadows across Kempenfelt Bay as Marcus Thompson laced up his worn running shoes on the front porch of his modest townhouse. The familiar ritual of preparing for his daily run had become second nature over the past fifteen years, but today felt different somehow. There was an electricity in the air that had nothing to do with the approaching storm clouds gathering over Lake Simcoe.

"You're up early again," came the sleepy voice of David from behind the screen door. Marcus turned to see his husband of eight years standing there in his rumpled pajamas, dark hair sticking up at impossible angles, holding two steaming mugs of coffee.

"Couldn't sleep," Marcus replied, accepting the offered mug gratefully. "Keep thinking about that phone call yesterday."

David settled onto the porch swing beside him, close enough that their shoulders touched. At thirty-four, Marcus still maintained the lean build of a serious runner, though the lines around his eyes spoke of years spent training under the harsh Canadian sun. David, two years younger and softer around the edges from his work as an accountant, had always been the practical one in their relationship.

"The talent show thing?" David asked, though he already knew the answer. They'd talked about little else since Marcus received the call informing him he'd made it through to the final round of Canada's Greatest Talent, a nationally televised competition that had been his secret obsession for months.

Marcus nodded, setting down his coffee to stretch his hamstrings against the porch railing. "I still can't believe they picked me. Out of thousands of applicants across the country, they want to see my running routine in the finals."

It hadn't been a traditional audition. Marcus had submitted a video of himself performing what he called "artistic running" – a combination of his natural speed and agility with choreographed movements that told a story through motion. He'd been inspired by watching his niece's dance recital the previous year, struck by how movement could convey emotion in ways that words never could.

The video he'd submitted showed him running through various locations around Barrie – along the waterfront, through Springwater Park, up and down the steep hills of the residential areas – but it wasn't just running. He'd incorporated elements of interpretive dance, using his entire body to express themes of struggle, perseverance, and ultimate triumph. The piece he'd created was called "Breaking Free," and it chronicled his own journey from a closeted teenager afraid to be himself to a man who'd found love and acceptance.

"When's the taping again?" David asked, though Marcus knew he remembered perfectly well.

"Next Thursday. They want all the finalists in Toronto by Wednesday evening for rehearsals." Marcus began his pre-run stretching routine, a series of movements so ingrained they required no conscious thought. "The show goes live on Friday night, prime time. Winner gets fifty thousand dollars and a chance to tour across Canada."

David was quiet for a moment, watching as Marcus worked through his stretches. They'd been together long enough that David could read his husband's moods like a favorite book, and right now he sensed an undercurrent of anxiety beneath Marcus's excitement.

"What aren't you telling me?" David asked gently.

Marcus paused mid-stretch, his expression shifting almost imperceptibly. This was the conversation he'd been dreading since yesterday's phone call. "They're not covering travel expenses for the finalists. I guess I assumed they would, but apparently that's only for the semi-finals and beyond if you make it that far."

"Okay, so we buy you a train ticket to Toronto. It's what, forty dollars?"

"It's not just the train ticket." Marcus resumed his stretching, not quite meeting David's eyes. "They want us there Wednesday through Saturday. Four nights in a hotel, meals, and I'd need to take time off work. Jim's already been on my case about taking too many personal days."

David set down his coffee mug with a soft clink. As the family's financial planner, he knew exactly how tight their budget had become over the past few months. His accounting firm had cut everyone's hours back in January, and Marcus's job at the sporting goods store barely covered their basic expenses. They'd been living paycheck to paycheck since David's mother had needed help with her medical bills the previous fall.

"How much are we talking about?" David asked, though from Marcus's expression he suspected he didn't want to know the answer.

"Best case scenario, if I stay somewhere cheap and eat nothing but fast food, probably around four hundred dollars. More realistically, closer to six or seven hundred."

David felt his stomach drop. They had maybe two hundred dollars in their checking account, and payday wasn't until the following Friday. Their credit cards were already maxed out from the expenses related to David's mother, and they'd borrowed against their small savings account twice already this year.

"We'll figure it out," David said automatically, though privately he was running through their options and coming up empty.

Marcus finally looked at him directly, and David could see the conflict written across his features. "Maybe I should just call them and withdraw. Tell them something came up."

"Absolutely not." David's response was immediate and firm. "This is your dream, Marcus. You've been working toward something like this your entire life."

It was true. Even when they'd first met at a New Year's Eve party nine years ago, Marcus had talked about wanting to find a way to combine his love of running with performance. He'd run competitively in high school and college, but had never been quite fast enough for the Olympic trials or professional circuits. The artistic running concept had emerged gradually over the years, starting as something he did just for fun during his solo training runs and evolving into something more structured and intentional.

"My dream doesn't matter if we can't afford groceries next month," Marcus said, but David could hear the disappointment in his voice.

"Let me look at our finances again tonight," David said. "Maybe I can pick up some freelance bookkeeping work this week. Mrs. Patterson has been asking me to help her organize her small business accounting."

Marcus smiled, but it didn't reach his eyes. "I love that you want to make this work, but I've seen our bank statements too. We both know the money just isn't there."

David stood up and pulled Marcus into a hug, breathing in the familiar scent of his husband's shampoo mixed with the faint smell of coffee. "We have six days to figure this out. Don't give up yet."

Marcus returned the embrace, allowing himself a moment to draw strength from David's unwavering support. This was why he'd fallen in love with this man – David's absolute refusal to let him settle for less than his dreams, even when practical considerations made those dreams seem impossible.

"I should get my run in," Marcus said finally, pulling back from the hug. "Clear my head a little bit."

"How far today?"

"Just five miles. I want to work on some of the choreography for the routine I'd perform if..." he trailed off, not wanting to jinx anything by talking about it too confidently.

David kissed him softly. "When you get there. When you perform your routine."

After Marcus disappeared down the street, his familiar red running shirt becoming a small dot in the distance, David remained on the porch with his coffee. He pulled out his phone and began scrolling through their banking app, looking for any overlooked source of funds. Their mortgage payment was due in two weeks, along with the car payment and David's student loan. They'd already cut their expenses to the bare minimum – cancelled their streaming services, started shopping at discount grocery stores, hadn't eaten at a restaurant in months.

The irony wasn't lost on him that Marcus's potential prize money would solve all their immediate financial problems, but they needed money to give him the chance to win money. It was the kind of catch-twenty-two situation that seemed to define their lives lately.

David's phone rang, interrupting his brooding. The caller ID showed his sister Jennifer's name.

"Morning, Jen. You're up early."

"Kids had me up at five-thirty for some reason. I figured I might as well embrace it and get some work done before they wake up again." Jennifer was a single mother of twin seven-year-olds and somehow managed to run her own graphic design business from home. David had no idea how she did it. "How are things with you guys?"

"Good. Well, mostly good." David found himself explaining about Marcus's opportunity and their financial dilemma.

"Oh wow, that's incredible about the talent show! I remember Marcus showing me some of those videos he made. He's really talented." Jennifer paused. "And really broke, apparently. How much did you say you need?"

"We can probably make it work with around four hundred dollars, but honestly even that feels impossible right now."

"I wish I could help, but with the kids starting soccer and needing new school clothes..." Jennifer's voice trailed off apologetically.

"I wasn't asking," David said quickly. "Just needed to talk it through with someone."

"What about Mom? Did you tell her about this?"

David hesitated. His mother lived in Ottawa and had been incredibly supportive when he'd come out and later when he'd married Marcus. But she was seventy-two and living on a fixed income, and he'd already asked her for help twice in the past year.

"I don't want to burden her with this," he said finally.

"Dave, she would want to know. And she might surprise you."

After they hung up, David sat on the porch swing and watched the neighborhood come alive around him. Mrs. Chen from next door was tending to her garden, and the Kowalski kids were riding their bikes in circles in their driveway. It was the kind of peaceful suburban scene that usually filled him with contentment, but today it felt somehow inadequate.

He'd grown up in Barrie, gone to university in Toronto, and returned home after graduation with vague plans of saving money for a year before moving to a bigger city. That year had turned into nine years, and somewhere along the way he'd stopped thinking about leaving. Meeting Marcus had anchored him here, and most of the time he was happy with their quiet life. But moments like this made him wonder if they'd been too cautious, too willing to settle for stability over opportunity.

His phone buzzed with a text message from his boss at the accounting firm: "Can you come in today? Jenkins called in sick and we have three client meetings scheduled."

David stared at the message for a long moment. It was his day off, and he'd planned to spend it working on their household budget and maybe doing some yard work. But extra hours meant extra money, even if it wasn't nearly enough to solve their current problem.

He texted back his agreement and went inside to shower and change clothes. As he got dressed, he found himself looking at the framed photograph on their dresser from their wedding day. They'd gotten married at a small ceremony in David's parents' backyard, surrounded by family and a handful of close friends. Marcus looked impossibly young in the photo, beaming as they cut their modest wedding cake. David remembered how certain they'd both felt that day that love would be enough to overcome any obstacles life threw at them.

The accounting firm of Peterson & Associates occupied the second floor of a converted heritage building in downtown Barrie. David had been working there for six years, starting as a junior associate and gradually working his way up to senior accountant. It wasn't glamorous work, but he was good at it and found satisfaction in helping clients organize their financial lives.

"Thanks for coming in on short notice," said Margaret Peterson when he arrived at the office. She was a woman in her early fifties who'd built the firm from nothing over the past twenty years. David respected her enormously, both professionally and personally. She'd been nothing but supportive when he'd needed time off for family emergencies, and she'd even attended his wedding.

"No problem. What do we have today?"

"The Hendersons at ten to go over their small business taxes, Mrs. Liu at noon for retirement planning, and the Jakobsons at two-thirty for their divorce settlement." Margaret handed him three manila folders. "Should be straightforward, but I know you like to review everything beforehand."

David settled at his desk and began reviewing the files, but found his concentration wandering. The Henderson file reminded him of Marcus's long-abandoned dream of opening his own running store someday. Mrs. Liu's retirement planning made him think about their own complete lack of retirement savings. And the Jakobsons' divorce settlement just made him grateful that whatever problems he and Marcus faced, they faced them together.

His first client meeting went smoothly. Tom and Linda Henderson had opened a small bakery the previous year and were struggling to understand their quarterly tax obligations. David walked them through the paperwork and set up a system for tracking their expenses that would make next year's filing much simpler.

"You're a lifesaver," Linda said as they prepared to leave. "We were completely overwhelmed by all of this."

"That's what I'm here for," David replied, but privately he was thinking about how the Henderson's bakery represented exactly the kind of entrepreneurial risk that he and Marcus had never been willing to take.

During his lunch break, David walked down to the waterfront and found himself standing at the same spot where Marcus often started his artistic running routines. He could picture his husband moving through the choreographed sequence – the initial slow, contemplative movements giving way to explosive bursts of speed, the way Marcus used the natural landscape as a stage for his storytelling.

David pulled out his phone and called his mother in Ottawa.

"David! What a lovely surprise. How are you, sweetheart?"

"I'm good, Mom. Listen, I wanted to tell you about something exciting that's happening with Marcus."

He explained about the talent show opportunity, trying to keep his tone upbeat and positive. His mother listened without interrupting, asking occasional clarifying questions.

"That's wonderful news! I'm so proud of him. When is the show?"

"Friday night, live on television. The thing is..." David found himself unable to continue, the words sticking in his throat.

"What is it, honey?"

"We're having trouble coming up with the money for him to get there and stay for the week. I feel terrible even mentioning it to you, especially after you helped us out with the car repair and everything, but I didn't know who else to talk to."

His mother was quiet for a long moment. "How much do you need?"

"Mom, I wasn't calling to ask for money. I just needed to talk to someone about it."

"David Michael Chen-Thompson, how much do you need?"

David smiled despite himself. His mother only used his full hyphenated name when she was being serious. "Probably around four hundred dollars, maybe five hundred to be safe."

"Consider it done. I'll transfer the money this afternoon."

"Mom, I can't ask you to do that."

"You're not asking. I'm offering. Marcus is part of this family, and this is his chance to shine. Besides, I've been saving up for a new couch, but the old one is perfectly comfortable for a few more months."

David felt tears prick at his eyes. "I don't know how to thank you."

"Just make sure I know what channel to watch on Friday night. I want to see my son-in-law on television."

After he hung up, David sat on a bench overlooking the bay and allowed himself to feel genuinely excited for the first time since Marcus had gotten the call. This was really happening. Marcus was going to get his chance to perform on national television, to share his unique artistic vision with the entire country.

He spent the rest of his lunch break calling hotels near the television studio in Toronto, eventually finding a small budget hotel that offered weekly rates. It wasn't glamorous, but it was clean and safe and within walking distance of the studio. He made a reservation using their credit card, knowing that his mother's transfer would cover it.

His afternoon client meetings passed in a blur of spreadsheets and tax forms, but David found himself energized in a way he hadn't been in months. There was something powerful about taking action to support the person you loved, about refusing to let financial constraints dictate the limits of possibility.

When he got home that evening, Marcus was in the kitchen preparing dinner – pasta with vegetables from their small garden and a simple tomato sauce. It was humble food, but Marcus had a way of making even the simplest meals feel special.

"How was work?" Marcus asked, looking up from the stove.

"Good. Actually, really good." David couldn't keep the smile off his face. "I talked to my mother today."

Marcus raised an eyebrow. "Oh?"

"She's transferring us five hundred dollars for your Toronto trip. She says she wants to watch her son-in-law on national television."

Marcus stared at him for a long moment, then set down his wooden spoon and pulled David into a fierce hug.

"I can't believe it," Marcus whispered against David's shoulder. "This is really happening."

"This is really happening," David confirmed, holding his husband tightly. "You're going to Toronto, you're going to perform your routine, and you're going to be amazing."

They held each other in the small kitchen as steam rose from the pasta pot and the evening sun slanted through the windows. For the first time in months, their modest life felt not like a limitation but like a foundation – solid ground from which Marcus could leap toward his dreams.

Chapter 2

The following morning arrived gray and drizzly, with the kind of persistent Ontario rain that seemed to seep into everything. Marcus stood at the kitchen window, watching droplets race down the glass while his coffee grew cold in his hands. The excitement from the previous evening had given way to a familiar anxiety that settled in his chest like a stone. He'd barely slept, his mind cycling through endless variations of what could go wrong in Toronto. What if his routine wasn't good enough? What if the other contestants were more polished, more professional? What if he froze up in front of the cameras and made a fool of himself on national television?

David emerged from the bedroom already dressed for work, his hair still damp from the shower. He moved through their morning routine with practiced efficiency – grabbing his travel mug from the cabinet, checking his phone for messages, gathering the papers he'd need for the day's client meetings. But Marcus noticed the way his husband's eyes kept finding him, the gentle assessment that meant David was reading his mood and adjusting accordingly.

"The rain's supposed to clear up by this afternoon," David said, settling beside Marcus at the small kitchen table with his own coffee. "Perfect running weather once the temperature drops a bit."

Marcus nodded absently, still staring out at the gray morning. "I keep thinking about what happens if I don't win. We'll have spent all that money for nothing, and I'll just be the guy from Barrie who thought he could dance while running." He finally turned away from the window, meeting David's steady gaze. "What if this whole thing is just some elaborate form of self-delusion? Maybe I'm not actually talented, maybe I'm just different enough that people don't know how to tell me the truth."

David reached across the table and covered Marcus's hand with his own. "Do you remember what you told me after that first time I saw you perform your routine? This was maybe three years ago, down at the waterfront. You'd been working on that piece about overcoming fear, and afterward I asked you why you did it."

Marcus smiled slightly at the memory. "I said it was the only time I felt like my body was saying exactly what I meant it to say."

"And that's still true, isn't it? When you're out there moving through your choreography, you're not performing for anyone else's approval. You're translating something internal into something physical, something visible." David squeezed his hand gently. "The fact that other people connect with it, that Canada's Greatest Talent saw something worth putting on television, that's just confirmation of what I already knew. You have a gift, Marcus. A real, legitimate gift."

The validation helped, but Marcus found himself thinking about the practical realities of the competition. "I've been researching the other finalists online. There's a twelve-year-old violinist who's already performed with the Toronto Symphony Orchestra. A comedian who's been headlining clubs in Vancouver for five years. A dance troupe from Montreal that's won international competitions." He pulled out his phone and showed David the Canada's Greatest Talent website, scrolling through professional headshots and impressive biographies. "And then there's me. Thirty-four-year-old guy from Barrie who works at a sporting goods store and runs around in interpretive patterns."

David studied the website for a moment, taking in the polished promotional materials and carefully crafted contestant profiles. "You know what I notice about all of these descriptions? They're all talking about technical achievements, awards, recognition from established institutions." He looked back at Marcus thoughtfully. "But none of them are talking about heart. None of them are talking about the kind of authentic emotional connection that you create when you perform."

"Heart doesn't win competitions," Marcus replied, though he could hear the doubt in his own voice.

"Maybe not. But it's what makes people remember you long after the competition is over." David stood up and began clearing their coffee mugs, moving through the familiar domestic choreography of their shared morning routine. "Besides, they didn't choose you by accident. Out of thousands of applicants, they saw something in your audition video that made them want more. Trust that instinct."

After David left for work, Marcus found himself alone with the peculiar energy that always preceded a major life event. He'd requested the week off from his job at Northern Sports, though his manager Jim had made it clear that he wasn't happy about the short notice. The store was heading into their busy fall season, and Marcus's absence would mean longer hours for everyone else. The guilt about that added another layer to his anxiety, but David had been right when he'd pointed out that opportunities like this didn't wait for convenient timing.

Marcus decided to spend the morning working on his routine, using their small living room as a makeshift rehearsal space. He'd performed the piece dozens of times over the past few weeks, refining the movements until they felt like second nature, but something about the approaching competition made everything feel uncertain again. The routine that had seemed powerful and moving in the familiar context of Barrie's waterfront trails suddenly felt inadequate when he imagined it on a television stage in front of millions of viewers.

The piece he'd prepared for the finals was an evolution of the "Breaking Free" routine from his audition video, expanded and refined to fill the five-minute time slot he'd been allotted. It began with slow, constrained movements that suggested imprisonment or limitation, gradually building through increasingly dynamic sequences that represented struggle, breakthrough, and ultimately liberation. The emotional arc was deeply personal, drawn from his own experience of accepting his sexuality and finding love, but he'd crafted it to speak to universal themes of overcoming obstacles and embracing authentic identity.

Working through the routine in their living room felt awkward and cramped. The movements that flowed naturally across open landscape felt stilted when performed between their couch and coffee table. Marcus found himself second-guessing choreographic choices that had felt inspired just weeks earlier. Should the initial sequence be slower, more contemplative? Was the transition to the explosive middle section too abrupt? Did the final triumphant movements read as genuine celebration or forced optimism?

By noon, he was frustrated and sweating despite the cool temperature. The routine felt mechanical, disconnected from the emotional truth that had originally inspired it. He decided to abandon the indoor rehearsal and head out for a run, hoping that movement through familiar territory would help him reconnect with the spirit of the piece.

The rain had stopped as David had predicted, leaving the air clean and cool with that particular freshness that followed Ontario storms. Marcus made his way down to the waterfront, nodding to the handful of other runners and dog walkers who were taking advantage of the break in the weather. The path along Kempenfelt Bay had been his training ground for years, and he knew every hill, every turn, every spot where the light fell differently depending on the time of day.

He started with an easy warm-up pace, letting his body settle into the familiar rhythm of foot strike and breath. This was the foundation of everything – the simple, meditative act of running that had been his constant companion since high school. Before the artistic elements, before the choreography, before the dreams of performance and recognition, there had been this: the pure joy of movement, the sense of freedom that came from pushing his body through space under his own power.

As his muscles warmed and his breathing deepened, Marcus began to incorporate elements of his routine. But instead of forcing the predetermined choreography, he let the movements emerge organically from his mood and the environment around him. A flock of geese taking flight from the bay inspired a series of ascending leaps. The way sunlight broke through the clouds and scattered across the water suggested a sequence of turning, spiraling movements that felt like celebration.

This was what David had been talking about – the difference between technical execution and authentic expression. When Marcus stopped trying to perform his routine and instead allowed his body to respond to the landscape and his own internal state, the movements regained their power and meaning. He wasn't just a guy running in interpretive patterns; he was a storyteller using his entire being as the medium for the story.

He spent nearly an hour working through different sections of the routine, experimenting with variations and refinements. A couple of times he noticed other people along the waterfront path stopping to watch, but instead of feeling self-conscious, he found their attention energizing. This was what performance was supposed to feel like – not the anxious attempt to meet external expectations, but the generous sharing of something authentic and meaningful.

By the time he made his way home, Marcus felt more centered than he had since receiving the phone call about the finals. The routine was good – more than good, it was genuinely powerful. He might not have the conventional credentials of some of the other contestants, but he had something that couldn't be taught in any academy or conservatory: a unique voice and the courage to use it.

David was already home when Marcus walked through the front door, sitting at their small dining table with his laptop open and papers spread around him. He looked up as Marcus entered, taking in his husband's flushed cheeks and bright eyes.

"Good run?" David asked, though Marcus's improved mood was obvious.

"Great run. I think I was overthinking everything this morning. Got back out to the waterfront and remembered why I do this in the first place." Marcus grabbed a glass of water and settled across from David at the table. "What are you working on?"

"Travel logistics, mostly. I've got your train tickets booked for Wednesday morning, arriving in Toronto at noon. The hotel reservation is confirmed, and I found a couple of decent restaurants within walking distance that won't break our budget." David turned his laptop screen toward Marcus, showing a detailed itinerary he'd prepared. "I also called the studio and confirmed the rehearsal schedule. You've got a technical run-through Wednesday at four, dress rehearsal Thursday afternoon, and then the live show Friday evening."

Marcus studied the schedule, feeling a mix of excitement and nervousness at seeing it all laid out so concretely. "This is really happening, isn't it?"

"This is really happening. And I have something else to tell you." David's expression shifted to something Marcus couldn't quite read – not bad news, but something significant. "I called in a couple of favors at work and managed to rearrange my client meetings for the end of the week. I'm coming with you."

Marcus stared at him. "David, we can't afford for both of us to go. The hotel room alone will cost more, and you'll miss work, and—"

"The hotel room costs the same whether it's one person or two people. I can bring my laptop and work remotely Thursday and Friday if needed. And honestly, the idea of you going through this alone while I sit here in Barrie worrying about you sounds terrible." David reached across the table and took Marcus's hand. "I want to be there. I want to watch you perform live, and I want to celebrate with you afterward regardless of what happens."

The gesture was so typical of David – quietly figuring out how to make something work, prioritizing Marcus's needs over his own comfort and convenience. Marcus felt a rush of gratitude so intense it was almost overwhelming. "Are you sure? I know how much you hate being away from home."

It was true. David was a creature of routine and familiar surroundings. He'd grown up in Barrie, gone to university in Toronto but come home every weekend, and had never shown any interest in travel or adventure for its own sake. The farthest they'd traveled together was a long weekend in Ottawa to visit David's mother, and even that had required weeks of planning and preparation.

"I hate the idea of missing this more than I hate being away from home," David said simply. "This is the biggest thing that's ever happened to you professionally. There's no way I'm watching it on television when I could be there in person."

They spent the rest of the afternoon working through the practical details of the extended trip. David called his mother to give her the updated schedule, and she immediately insisted that they stay an extra day in Toronto so she could drive down from Ottawa to take them out for a celebration dinner. Marcus called his sister in Thunder Bay to make sure she knew to watch the show, and found himself explaining his artistic running concept to her teenage daughters, who seemed genuinely fascinated by the idea.

As evening approached, they prepared dinner together in their small kitchen, working around each other with the practiced ease of years of shared domestic life. Marcus found himself paying attention to these small moments – the way David hummed unconsciously while chopping vegetables, the familiar ritual of setting their table, the comfortable silence that fell between them as they ate. In three days, they would be in Toronto, surrounded by television cameras and production crews and the intense energy of live broadcast. But this – their quiet life in Barrie, their modest home, their simple routines – this would still be here waiting for them when they returned.

After dinner, they walked down to the waterfront together, following the same route Marcus had taken during his afternoon run. The sun was setting over Lake Simcoe, painting the sky in shades of orange and pink that reflected off the still water. Other couples and families were out enjoying the mild evening, and Marcus felt a deep sense of belonging to this place and these people.

"Whatever happens in Toronto," Marcus said as they settled on a bench overlooking the bay, "I'm grateful for this. For you, for the opportunity, for the fact that we figured out how to make it work."

David leaned against his shoulder, solid and warm in the cooling air. "Whatever happens in Toronto, we'll handle it together. But I have a good feeling about this, Marcus. I think you're going to surprise a lot of people."

They sat in comfortable silence as the light faded and the first stars began to appear in the darkening sky. In less than seventy-two hours, Marcus would be performing his routine on national television, sharing his unique artistic vision with millions of viewers across Canada. The thought was both thrilling and terrifying, but sitting there with David beside him and the familiar landscape of home spread out before them, Marcus felt ready for whatever came next.

Chapter 3

Wednesday morning arrived with the kind of crisp autumn clarity that made everything seem possible. Marcus woke before his alarm, his body humming with nervous energy that felt different from the anxiety of the past few days. This was anticipation now, the electric feeling of standing at the edge of something significant. David was already awake beside him, propped up on one elbow and watching Marcus with the patient attention he'd perfected over their years together.

"How are you feeling?" David asked, his voice still rough with sleep.

Marcus considered the question seriously, taking inventory of the sensations coursing through him. His stomach was tight with nerves, but underneath that was a steady current of excitement that reminded him of Christmas mornings as a child. "Scared. Excited. Ready, I think." He rolled over to face David fully. "I keep thinking about all the things that could go wrong, but then I remember how the routine felt yesterday afternoon by the water. It's good, David. Whatever happens with the competition part, the art itself is good."

They had packed the night before, laying out everything Marcus would need for the week in Toronto. His performance outfit – simple black athletic wear that would allow for maximum movement – was folded carefully in tissue paper. David had insisted on bringing their good camera to document the experience, and Marcus had packed the journal he'd been keeping throughout his artistic running journey, thinking he might want to write about whatever happened in the coming days.

The train to Toronto departed at nine-thirty, which meant they needed to leave Barrie by eight-fifteen to account for parking and ticket collection. As they moved through their morning routine – shower, coffee, final check of their luggage – Marcus found himself memorizing details of their ordinary life. The way morning light slanted through their kitchen window, the familiar sounds of their neighborhood waking up, the comfortable rhythm of preparing for a day that they'd repeated hundreds of times before. After today, something fundamental would be different. Win or lose, succeed or fail, he would never again be the person who had only dreamed of performing his art on a national stage.

David loaded their bags into their modest Honda Civic while Marcus did a final walk-through of the house. He found himself pausing in their living room, looking at the space where he'd rehearsed so many times over the past weeks. The furniture was pushed back against the walls to create a makeshift performance area, and suddenly the room felt too small to contain all the dreams and preparation it had witnessed. In a few hours, he would be in a professional television studio with proper lighting and sound equipment and an audience of millions. The thought made him dizzy with possibility.

"Ready?" David called from the doorway, keys jingling in his hand.

Marcus took one more look around their home, then nodded. "Ready."

The drive to the train station passed in comfortable conversation about logistics and timing, but Marcus could sense the undercurrent of significance that ran beneath their practical planning. This wasn't just a trip to Toronto; this was the culmination of years of artistic development and personal growth. Every choice they'd made – David's decision to come along, his mother's financial support, Marcus's commitment to taking time off work despite his manager's disapproval – had led them to this moment.

At the station, they joined the moderate crowd of Wednesday morning travelers heading into the city. Business people with laptops and coffee, students returning to university after a long weekend at home, tourists with cameras and guidebooks. Marcus wondered if any of them would be watching Canada's Greatest Talent on Friday night, if they would remember seeing him on the train when his face appeared on their television screens.
